{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3392237,"name":"Ashwin Naren","username":"anaren","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/ccd318/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-26T20:46:14.561Z","cooked":"

I’ve seen quite a few posts about Orin Nano’s, so I figured I’d write a post about what our team did https://www.pixelators.org/blog/2024_5_25_orin_coprocessor/.

You can find our code for the Orin on GitHub.

TL;DR We used ros2 and wrote a networking node in rust, and then sent the data to the RIO via a custom UDP protocol.

In the article you mentioned the price limit is $700 but for the 2024 season it was $600.

FRC Rules Search

Rule R301

R301      *Individual item cost limit. No individual, non-KOP item or software shall have a Fair Market Value (FMV) that exceeds $600 USD. The total cost of COMPONENTS purchased in bulk may exceed $600 USD as long as the cost...

we enabled IMU fusion to get a more accurate position as we had a RealSense camera with an internal IMU.

Depending on which RealSense camera you are using (couldn’t find this detail in the posting), the IMU is subject to jumping from any abrupt hit or fast turning. It might work great isolated in a lab, but on a real field outside of Auton I wouldn’t trust it to stay accurate.

If there is anyway to fuse a pigeon or something else in instead, I’d wholly recommend this method. There are other Sensor Fusion packages available in ROS that you can supply a target imu data topic of your choosing. These can also take in your wheel Odom as well to help stabilize the jumping. Some RealSense cameras support wheel_odom as well, again depends on the model. The T265 was the best motion tracking camera available when I was working with them. Still wasn’t gonna be accurate over the course of a whole match on its own.

Welp, just a typo on my end, the Orin was still under $600 when purchased.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-05-28T17:34:05.148Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":97,"readers_count":96,"score":34.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":466921,"topic_slug":"adventures-with-an-orin-nano","display_username":"Ashwin Naren","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":60828,"username":"Dave1998","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/a88e57/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66782,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software"},"post_url":"/t/adventures-with-an-orin-nano/466921/5","custom_user_title":"Software","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3392825,"name":"Ashwin Naren","username":"anaren","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/ccd318/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-28T17:46:17.069Z","cooked":"

If there is anyway to fuse a pigeon or something else in instead, I’d wholly recommend this method. There are other Sensor Fusion packages available in ROS that you can supply a target imu data topic of your choosing. These can also take in your wheel Odom as well to help stabilize the jumping. Some RealSense cameras support wheel_odom as well, again depends on the model.

We had two cameras that we were using interchangeably, the D435 and the D435i. We didn’t program IMU fusion ourselves, there was a setting on the ROS 2 node that we configured. I’m assuming you’re referring to using a separate IMU, which is possible, it’s just not supported by the ros2 node, and we would have to do with our own code. The NVIDIA provided SLAM node has limited configuration in this regard, and you are expected to do the work yourself. It does however support feeding in an wheel odom pose, which we do, but i’m unsure how much this affects the output.

The T265 was the best motion tracking camera available when I was working with them. Still wasn’t gonna be accurate over the course of a whole match on its own.

Were you using VSLAM, if so, I would believe the accuracy of VSLAM depends heavily on what coprocesser is chosen, if I recall VSLAM alone (no IMU) was originally very inaccurate in testing, but the April Tags and IMU helped mitigate that. We also were only using it in auto, as we didn’t use any paths in TeleOp.
